awd_titl_txt: Facility Support: Accelerator Mass Spectrometry at PRIME Lab
awd_abstract_narration:
The Purdue Rare Isotope Measurement Laboratory (PRIME Lab) is a national, multi-user facility dedicated to the measurement of cosmogenic radionuclides using accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS).  This award will provide management and operations support for this facility.  Significant geologic processes occur over a wide variety of time-scales. Catastrophic changes, large debris flows or floods, occur over short time-scales but other changes, such as long-term erosion of landscape or glacial cycles occur over longer time-scales, thousands to millions of years. These changes nonetheless play a dominant role in landscape evolution and directly impact the welfare of human populations world-wide. Measuring the rates of these processes and reconstructing a chronology for them is a challenge and geoscientists employ a number of tools to extract this information from the geologic archive. Cosmic-ray produced nuclides, especially those measured by accelerator mass spectrometry, are now routinely used to obtain chronologies and determine erosion rates for significant geologic processes. In the last decade these nuclides have been used to reconstruct glacial chronologies, which in turn provides a record of past climates. They have also been used to show linkages between tectonic activity and erosion rates. The pursuit of these studies has involved PhD students and researchers from dozens of universities within the US. At PRIME Lab they not only learn how to perform the physical and chemical preparation of samples, but they also participate in the measurement of their samples on the PRIME Lab accelerator mass spectrometry system. The interaction between students, faculty, and professional staff at PRIME facilitates interaction with geologists, chemists, and physicists, providing a near unique opportunity to expand the educational opportunity beyond the focus of the research projects. 

With continued NSF support, PRIME Lab will continue utilizing the unique capabilities of a larger accelerator for the benefit of the geoscience community. Given the limited number of multi-isotope facilities in the US, we anticipate growth in the number of measurements (and sample preparation) required by the geoscience community. In addition to more routine measurements, we are the only laboratory in the US positioned to advance the state-of-the-art using a gas-filled-magnet. We have already demonstrated the efficacy of the instrumentation for 10Be, 26Al, and 36Cl, especially 26Al. For the next five years, PRIME Lab will continue to advance the application of cosmogenic nuclides in the geosciences through increased productivity of routinely measured nuclides and by the development of new measurement technologies and applications harnessing these advances.

por.por_cntn:
The last 6 years have been the most productive in PRIME Lab history. During this time we have measured with high precision thousands of samples from investigators from the NSF and outside, national labs, federal agenices, and instutions spanning the world. 

We are one of the few facilities that can measure all the routinely measured radionuclides, and we offer chemical prepaartion facilities for all these nuclides. We also happily teach these techniques to scientists from all over the world. 

COVID has nonetheless, had an outsize negative impact on our operations.At the beginning of this summer, we had over 1500 10Be samples awaiting measurement. That is more than we've ever had backlogged. We've run over 800 of them this summer, and while more have come in, we anticipate being able to largely knock out the backlog during the remainder of this calendar year. We have no backlog of Al, Cl, C, or I. 

It is also the case that our chemical preparation laboratories have been as productive as ever. Most of these samples are for outside users, and we are one of the few laboratories in the US that have this capability. It is worth mentioning that our laboratories are pretty maxed out, and we encourage others to prepare cathodes.

During the last 5 years the precision of our measurements has continued to improve, and most 10Be measurements have a precision better than 5%, many better than %. We see this continuing to improve. We have also participated in several inter-comparisons using standards. These experiments provide confidence to the user community in our measurement capability, and also demonstate the ability to compare measurements at different laboratories.

A particular focus has been on improving day-to-day operations. PRIME Lab is an older facility, and while most aspect of the beamlines have been modernized there are always components that tend to fail. We have focused on those. In partiuclar we have done considerable work inside the tandem on the mechanical structures. We have aligned chains better, made better high-voltage connections to charging system elements, and put in better spark suppression. We also installed a new accelerator tube. The result of all this is an accelerator that is running superbly. At the time of this writing the accelerator has been running nearly daily for almost 6 months. This is outstanding, and while a failure could occur at any time, it is conceivable we won't have to go inside the tandem for months yet. The stability is better than it has ever been, which is reflected in high-precision data. 

Perhaps the most important outcome for a National Facility is its outreach to the scientific community, NSF and beyond. The table itemizes the PRIME Lab user facility during this proposal period. It comprises more than 240 users. If a particular user has more than one project, which many do, the user is only listed once. The number of projects far exceeds list listing. Several things are noteworthy. PRIME Lab is providing as essential capability to the NSF geoscience community. But this service goes far beyond measurement, we teach field techniques through collaboration, laboratory techniques, and provide consultation on the application of these techniques. PRIME Lab measurements are utilized by national laboratories in the US, other federal agencies, and we have a large international footprint.
